name/tag of non-tripleo container we pull in downstream ci is different from what we have in upstream. Even incase of any of downstream container fails to pull, we will not find downstream specific container image/tag in upstream failover registries.

~~~

  image_source: prom
- imagename: quay.ceph.io/prometheus/alertmanager:v0.16.2

openshift-ose-prometheus-node-exporter:v4.1
openshift-ose-prometheus:4-2

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Something that would help in review is a quick note about how this makes it better.  It doesn't actually look any simpler, it just looks different.

It looks like you see the UnparsedAbideConfig holding a list of tenants when it should really be a dictionary, because we should only ever have a single tenant YAML block for a tenant.

The user-facing config of Zuul is always a list of items, rather than a dict, because (a) many of them can be repeated in order to achieve the 'variant' behavior that we rely on, but even cases where there should be a single definition, we like lists of dicts because (b) duplicating a key in a yaml dict can lead to an undetectable error.

The internal data structure in Zuul for all of the regular user-facing objects mirrors that to make things easier.

We copied that into the tenant config too, again for consistency.  However, we never defined an overlay behavior like the variants described in (a), and it looks like we make assumptions that there is only ever a single tenant object with a given name.  I tried out some tests, and the behavior is... undefined at best.  It looks like we might even, to some extent, load two separate tenants with the same name, but then have things fail when we try to use them.

In the future, we might want to support overlayed tenant definitions, or tenants with regex names, but we don't now.

I think we can go ahead and make the idea of a single yaml-dict per tenant official, and raise an exception if the same name appears twice.  I think we should do that as part of this change though, since this change may cause something that would have failed loudly before to fail silently now (with this change, we would always just use the last block.

I implemented this in a followup.

Thanks for the explanation on why it was implemented that way. I indeed made the mistake to assume that there can only be a single tenant with the same name w/o checking the config format (I'm a little spoiled by the meta config that we use internally).

> Something that would help in review is a quick note about how this makes it better.  It doesn't actually look any simpler, it just looks different.

I did not intend this to be a change in behavior, but to make easier to work with in the configloader. For my taste it simplifies the code, but I guess that's subjective. Now, knowing the context, I think we at least got rid of some undefined behavior, especially with your follow-up change (thanks for that).

The naming is confused. I think the metadata "update_failure_no_rollback" really means skipping app recovery on update failure.

The operation perform_app_rollback is used when updating to the app that was perviously applied.
ie.. If hello-kitty 2.0 is currently running and hello-kitty 1.0 was applied before, system application-update to 1.0 will do perform_no_rollback internally. 

The operation perform_app_recover is used for app recovery if application-update(perform_app_apply/perform_app_rollback) fails.

Suggest to rename to skip_recovery or no_recovery.
I think rename to APP_PROGRESS_UPDATE_FAILED_SKIP_RECOVERY is more clear.
Should we not check the skip_recovery flag here before doing the rollback?

As Angie mentioned in a previous comment, this logic block is used when updating from N+1 to N.
The confusion arises here because the armada operation in this case is named 'rollback' and sysinv logic blocks(wrappers over armada operations) kept this name. Rollback here means downgrade.
would it be more accurate to add "or it failed but skip_recovery was set" here?

It seems a little risky to rely on nobody in the future assigning to "result" between line 2517 and here given how generic a name it is.  Might make sense to save it as "operation_successful" or something.

manifests/function/workers-capm3/kustomi.message: Let's move this one back to the site phase -- that'll set up the pattern where a user can supply their own catalogues if they like (rather than inheriting from airshipctl), like we will be doing for cloud harbor.  One other reason: if this function pulls in catalogues, and another function pulls in the same catalogues, then when those functions get customized together kustomize would complain about the duplicate catalogues

deployment/cephadm/ceph-osd.yaml.message:
My understanding is the CephOsdCount and CephOsdType parameters are only used by the HCI derived parameters feature. I don't know of something could be added to the parameter names (even just 'Hci'). Otherwise, is there a risk the user will feel they must provide valid values? For example, I think you could set CephOsdCount to a wacky number, and nothing would happen unless it's an HCI deployment and you ask it to derive the HCI parameters.

Also, are HCI nodes required to be homogeneous? Or do these need to be role dependent?

I've changed the name to CephHciOsdCount and CephHciOsdType as suggested.
HCI nodes can be role dependent.
I have a lot to clean up on the depends-on patch.

But yeah, will check it out

files/rename-nics.yaml.message:
This will all end up being a single line, so to improve readability I'd suggest:

    line: >
      SUBSYSTEM=="net",
      ACTION=="add",
      DRIVERS=="?*", 
      ATTR{address}=="{{ ansible_facts[item]['perm_macaddress'] | default(ansible_facts[item]['macaddress']) }}",
      NAME="{{ item|replace('eth',prefix) }}"

According to [1] it should be ens
as 
interfaces are PCI hot plugged if we look at "virsh dumpxml" output.

<address type='pci' domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x03' function='0x0'/>



[1] https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames/
That is fair, but this playbook is a copy of what is in our docs. I suggest registering a bug for this issue to resolve it in docs, then we can also resolve it here.
Thanks Jesse, that's what I wanted to answer too. We should correct it in the source first, then we can adapt it here.

If we remove this check and try to create an external network without passing the --apic-nat-type argument the create with fail with below error:
BadRequestException: 400, Invalid input for apic:nat_type. Reason: None is not in valid_values.

Instead of removing the parsed_args.apic_nat_type check, we can change it to:
parsed_args.apic_nat_type is not None:
This will resolve the above error as well as support apic_nat_type = ""

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: comment should be extended for reason for the constant value selected (and that it's temporary until the first unlock).
is there any way to pick this up from the sysinv constant to avoid defining it in multiple places?

There is not much value added in doing so.
During the initial deployment this change has no real meaning.
During the restore procedure, between restore_platform playbook and unlock, there is a window in which user app pods can misbehave. I agree that the thinking is to change once, affect what is needed, but here we don't need to place any value in particular.
The user apps are in fact intended to run after the unlock anyway. After the unlock the correct value is used, the one generated by sysinv as hieradata.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/const.message: How did we choose 500 as a minimum?

Running pods in namespaces armada, cert-manager, kube-system, vault showed <20 processes.

Running pods in monitor showed <30 processes.

Running pods in openstack showed the same with 2 exceptions ~450 libvirt and nova-compute pods. Both libvirt and nova-compute pods on the same node showed the same number of proceses. No openstack VM was running. No VM was manually deployed to not affect the running sanity.
If the libvirt and nova-compute pods are using 450 pids in steady state, it feels like 500 is cutting it a bit close for the default.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/scripts/sysinv-cond.message: Isn't armada running in a pod now? Why would we still be using docker to stop an armada_service container? Can Bob/Jim please comment?

what values were measured for the docker stop operation (on swact, sm-restart service sysinv-conductor)?

The current SM timeout appears to be about 20s.

I have updated LP with a comment, showing when request from SM happens, then reaching the docker stop and then SM times out.

From the comment, SM request takes less than 1s to reach docker stop and then it gets stuck for ~20s. Docker should take up to ~10s to stop/kill container but it is taking at least ~20s and then SM times out and retries. I don't know why docker stop command did not exit after 10s, but I'm sure it is not exiting because the messages from line 304 or 307 do not appear in logs for the failing scenario.

I don't think there was a problem with the docker stop. Looks to me like the timeout for the "sysinv-conductor stop" action in SM is only 20s. The logs in the LP (from line 371) indicate that SIGTERM didn't work so the script waited for 15s. That leaves only 5s until SM gives up on this action, so the default 10s timeout for the "docker stop" wouldn't kick in. Is this OCF written incorrectly now? Is the SIGTERM always going to time out if we have containers running? If so, shouldn't we be doing the docker stop FIRST, then trying the SIGTERM?
This was only observed for swact, in a successful scenario this is close to 1s, otherwise it might take up to 20s (probably SM times out and tries again).
This should also be measured for the general sm-restart case (as performed on patch).  If it can take up to 20s (and succeed) then this timeout should be increased

Yes, by default docker stop awaits for 10s and in case it times out, docker kill is issued. The problem is that in the observed issue the container wasn't stopped or killed for some reason, so this makes me think that docker stop --timeout might have the same problem, this is why timeout was used and in case container wasn't stopped, we try to kill it manually.
This would also be done at line 382 anyways?
You are correct, this will be removed.
This check appears to be redundant though with the check already at line 302?
In this part I'm just verifying if container was killed or not, I'm not trying to remove the stopped container. This might help for debugging future issues.

roles/overcloud-deploy/templates/config-.message:
James, I didn't find why we are making these changes in this file in commit message.
Could you please share some context on why this is needed.
it's needed because with ephemeral-heat, there is no Heat->Neutron, so we must update the file to work with network-data-v2
This would change it for all branches. We don't use deployed server for all scenarios.

are you asking about scenarios or branches? Scenarios that don't use this file do not use deployed-server are not affected by the change.

This is actually fine to change for all branches, and probably what it should have been set to originally. All we are doing is noop'ing and using a fixed ip for the control plane vip. That's necessary with ephemeral Heat due to the network-data-v2 changes to provision the vips separately.

Why're we changing these for < wallaby? They're already mapped for those branches[1] 
That way we can specify different service vips for RedisVirtualFixedIPs and OVNDBsVirtualFixedIPs as those are now created by external_deploy_tasks[2]

[1]https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/victoria/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml#L85-L86

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/ovn/ov
n-dbs-container-puppet.yaml#L243

> These aren't new lines I added, I only add the guard based on the branch.

Not sure I understand. I don't see  OS::TripleO::Network::Ports::RedisVipPort/OS::TripleO::Network::Ports::OVNDBsVipPort mapped[1] to noop.yaml before this change.

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network/ports/noop.yaml does not use FixedIPs (RedisVirtualFixedIPs or RedisVirtualFixedIPs) provided.

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/blob/master/roles/overcloud-deploy/templates/config-download.yaml.j2
ok, i think if i guard the new ControlPlaneVipPort Mapping then I can remove these mappings for < wallaby. I'll try it.

Actually, I don't think a change is needed here. For deployed-server, we can't use the default mappings for < wallaby. You'll notice these mappings do not match the defaults you linked. These aren't new lines I added, I only add the guard based on the branch. When using ephemeral Heat, we don't need the mappings, that's why I've now guarded them with the branch check.

This would override https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/40528d4a86aa9f4068a9a0acaf8b9aa989deb54b/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml#L82 (non-deployed-server). So heat won't create that port anymore and use 192.168.24.100.

I would have preferred to not change how it used to work before. But it's probably ok.
Probably could have restricted use_neutron only for newer releases.

> If we scale up a node, it won't have a nova.conf file thus not triggering the set_fact "defer_reboot" task at line 198. This means that TSX will be forcibly disabled on the node and the node will be rebooted making the tsx=off part of the running config once it's completely scaled up, just like the other nodes.
> 
> Where it might be problematic is if the operator ran a minor update to latest 16.1.x with no running instance, followed by a scale up, again with no running instances. I presume that we would have the original nodes having tsx=off in their grub config but not active configuration (not rebooted). The newly scaled up nodes would end up with tsx=off as running config.
> 
> One way to prevent this from being problematic is to disable defer_reboot if there's no running instances on a compute node where we flip the tsx flag. Would it be too agressive?

That's why I tend to only disable TSX on complete new 16.1 deployment. Instead of checking if there are instances, check if the nova endpoint is already registered. If the endpoint is registered we expect it is an existing deployment and leave tsx=on, otherwise it is a new deployment. Otherwise we end up in a mix of tsx=off/on computes and live migration can fail.

If we scale up a node, it won't have a nova.conf file thus not triggering the set_fact "defer_reboot" task at line 198. This means that TSX will be forcibly disabled on the node and the node will be rebooted making the tsx=off part of the running config once it's completely scaled up, just like the other nodes.

Where it might be problematic is if the operator ran a minor update to latest 16.1.x with no running instance, followed by a scale up, again with no running instances. I presume that we would have the original nodes having tsx=off in their grub config but not active configuration (not rebooted). The newly scaled up nodes would end up with tsx=off as running config.

One way to prevent this from being problematic is to disable defer_reboot if there's no running instances on a compute node where we flip the tsx flag. Would it be too agressive?

> We initially wanted to leverage the StackAction (CREATE or UPDATE), but if an operator re-run the deploy command post heat stack creation (ie: like in a case of an early failure), the StackAction will be UPDATE.

is the "upgrade_tasks" section not useful to differetiate the upgrade scenarios?

For fresh deployment, we want to forcefully set tsx to off, if cpu supports it. For already deployed environment, we want to forcefully set tsx to on, this is because it's already defaulted to "on" in rhel <= 8.2 and we want to allow live-migrations between nodes. 

TsxEnabled is an internal parameter and is set to off or on depending, respectively, if the environment was freshly deployed or if the patch has been installed the first time on an already deployed environment.

We initially wanted to leverage the StackAction (CREATE or UPDATE), but if an operator re-run the deploy command post heat stack creation (ie: like in a case of an early failure), the StackAction will be UPDATE.

These conditions have lower precedence on operator's provided kernelargs.

I'm currently looking for a way to get the same accuracy with overcloud status.

I thinking of options, have to be validated how it should be handled. 

Assumption: 
1) Fresh: If "KernelArgs" has "tsx=on" and node supports, kernel args are left as it is
2) Fresh: If "KernelArgs" has "tsx=on" and node not supports, kernel args are modified (REMOVE)
3) Fresh: If "KernelArgs" does not have "tsx" and node supports, kernel args modified (ADD tsx=off)
4) Upgrade: If "KernelArgs" has "tsx=on" and node supports, kernel args are left as it is
4) Upgrade: If "KernelArgs" does not have "tsx" and node supports, kernel args modified (ADD tsx=on)

Currently TRIPLEO_HEAT_TEMPLATE_KERNEL_ARGS in /etc/default/grub is used to store "KernelArgs" and merge it. If we can introduce another entry like TRIPLEO_HEAT_TEMPLATE_KERNEL_ARGS_OVERRIDE. This entry will be updated incase of (3) by deploy_tasks and (4) by upgrade_tasks. Since both will check for the existence of this entry, sync can be acheived. When we move this implementation inside the tripleo-ansible, it can he handled better. We also avoding the reboot in case of upgrade and kernel args are changed. Let me know whether it can cover all cases.

I believe the issue with the upgrade_tasks is that, on subsequent deploy, we'll loose the state of the flag. So if the patch was first executed during an upgrade, tsx must always be set to on, and if it was first executed during a new deployment, tsx must always be set to off, unless specified otherwise by the operator.

If you have an idea on how to achieve this computed persistency, we're open to ideas.

Saravanan, nice break down, that looks like we wanted it. After discussing with James Slagle, we might explore the path of just checking all the compute nodes and see if any of these would have tsx=on, if so, we'd enable it everywhere, by using TRIPLEO_HEAT_TEMPLATE_KERNEL_ARGS_OVERRIDE.

A point to note. If we are applying kernel args based on support then there will be a mismatch of parameter "KernelArgs" and actual values applied. A better way to implement this should have been via enable disable flag and enable it only when it is available in the platform (but KernelArgs are not implemented such a way).

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
oh, this makes it a little faster and avoid duplicate entries in the report

OMM with several thousand shards this method takes O(10) seconds

OMM, I had a DB that needed

* 10.2s before this change,
* 6.0s with this change, and
* 0.36s with my follow-up.

Note that I only expect that sort of improvement in the common case; there are definitely cases where it'll still take a while. In particular, if I add an extra range that covers the whole namespace, I saw no real difference between this change and my follow-up. I *did* see some difference in the number of overlaps found with that extra cover-everything range, though -- I don't remember which was which now, but I saw one run report 3130 overlap sets, another with 3132, and a third with 3133.
Tim I see you have a follow up to make it faster.. how much faster if you run it on the same one Al ran it on?
this shard_range != sr change here seems to be the crux of the fix
oh yeah that's right. Same upper and lower equaleth the ShardRange.. not great in this situation. Adding the name check means they'll actually cause it to check for olverlaps.

I wonder if something like

 diff --git a/swift/common/utils.py b/swift/common/utils.py
 index 950ef41a6..ba2373d1e 100644
 --- a/swift/common/utils.py
 +++ b/swift/common/utils.py
 @@ -5518,7 +5518,8 @@ class ShardRange(object):
          # test for equality of range bounds only
          if not isinstance(other, ShardRange):
              return False
 -        return self.lower == other.lower and self.upper == other.upper
 +        return (self.lower == other.lower and self.upper == other.upper and
 +                self.name == other.name)
  
      # A by-the-book implementation should probably hash the value, which
      # in our case would be account+container+lower+upper (+timestamp ?).

would be good, though -- I don't remember why we wrote that comment. OTOH, I'm also not sure where else we might test shard ranges for equality...

ideally I would retire this method and use find_paths() to discover overlaps, so that the result is same as the s-m-s-r repair command, but I was worried that would lead to all sorts of churn, and that the log messages would be hard to maintain as-is....but I also wonder how usefult the log messages are right now??
We could used find_paths to detect overlaps and just log "overlaps found" with no further detail - are the bounds of interest in logs or would op just use s-m-s-r repair or analyze anyway

We should look at using more analyse related checking in audit so they become more intergrated into the sharder. So +1 for this as a follow up, even if it's just a WIP so we can see what it'll look like.
one warning line seems like enough for me
